problems.title: Polynomial Addition using Linked List
problems.description:
Problem Statement:
Given two polynomials represented using Singly Linked Lists, where each node contains a coefficient and a power (exponent), perform polynomial addition and return the resulting polynomial in decreasing order of powers. Each linked list node is represented as (coefficient, power). If two terms have the same power, add the coefficients. Terms with resulting coefficient 0 should be removed. Display the final polynomial in the format: coeff power_coeff coeff power ...

Example Explanation:
Polynomial 1: 3x^3 + 2x^1 + 5
Polynomial 2: 5x^2 + 6x^1 + 8
After addition: 3x^3 + 5x^2 + 8x^1 + 13
Output Format: 3 3 5 2 8 1 13 0
hintsList: Use a merge-like traversal: compare powers and add coefficients when powers match.
Skip terms where the resulting coefficient becomes zero.

problems.title: Detect Loop in Linked List
problems.description:
Problem Statement:
Given N integers, create a Singly Linked List (SLL) by inserting nodes at the end. You are also given an additional integer P which represents the position (1-based index) where the last node should link back to create a loop. If P = 0, no loop should be created. Your task is to detect whether a loop exists in the linked list. Print "YES" if a loop is detected, otherwise print "NO".
Use Floyd’s Cycle Detection Algorithm (fast and slow pointers) for optimal performance.

Example Explanation:
Input: N = 5, List = [1 2 3 4 5], P = 2 → last node connects to node with value 2, so loop exists. Output = YES
hintsList: Use Floyd’s Cycle Detection (slow and fast pointer).
If fast meets slow, there is a loop.

problems.title: Remove Loop from Linked List
problems.description:
Problem Statement:
Given N integers, create a Singly Linked List (SLL) by inserting nodes at the end. You are also given an integer P which represents the position (1-based index) where the last node should link back to create a loop. If P = 0, no loop should be created. Your task is to detect the loop and then remove it, restoring the list to a linear linked list. After removing the loop, display the linked list from head to tail. If the list becomes empty, print -1.
Use Floyd’s Cycle Detection Algorithm to identify the loop and then remove it without losing nodes.

Example Explanation:
For input N = 5, List = [1 2 3 4 5], P = 2 → a loop is created from last node back to node with value 2.
After removing the loop, list becomes: 1 2 3 4 5
So output: 1 2 3 4 5

starterCodes.problemTitle: Remove Loop from Linked Linked List
Remove Loop from Linked Linked List
Remove Loop from Linked Linked List
Remove Loop from Linked Linked List
Remove Loop from Linked Linked List

hintsList: Use Floyd’s cycle detection to find the meeting point.
To remove loop, move one pointer to head and move both one step until next pointers match.

problems.title: Merge Two Sorted Linked Lists
problems.description:
Problem Statement:
Given two sorted Singly Linked Lists (SLL), merge them into a single sorted linked list in non-decreasing order. The merged list should reuse existing nodes and should not create new nodes. Display the final merged linked list. If both lists are empty, print -1.

Example Explanation:
List1 = 1 -> 3 -> 5
List2 = 2 -> 4 -> 6
Merged Result = 1 2 3 4 5 6
hintsList: Use two pointers to traverse both lists while linking the smaller node first.
When one list ends, link the remaining portion of the other list.

problems.title: Check if Linked List is Palindrome
problems.description:
Problem Statement:
Given N integers, create a Singly Linked List (SLL) by inserting nodes at the end. Determine whether the linked list is a palindrome. A palindrome list reads the same forward and backward. Print "YES" if it is a palindrome, otherwise print "NO". Use an optimized approach by finding the middle, reversing the second half, and then comparing both halves.

Example Explanation:
For input [1 2 3 2 1], the linked list reads the same from both directions, so output is YES.

Compare the first half with the reversed second half to determine if it is a palindrome.
